Item 1. Business.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART I - Item 1. Business section in bullet points:

• ENPH was founded in March 2006.
• As of December 31, 2024, ENPH has shipped approximately 80.0 million microinverters.
• Approximately 4.7 million Enphase residential and commercial systems have been deployed in more than 160 countries.
• The company designs, develops, manufactures, and sells home energy solutions that manage energy generation, storage, and control on one intelligent platform.
• ENPH has revolutionized the solar industry by pioneering a semiconductor-based microinverter that converts energy at the individual solar module level.

Item 1A. Risk Factors.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART I - Item 1A. Risk Factors section in bullet points:

• The reduction, elimination or expiration of government subsidies and economic incentives for on-grid solar electricity applications could reduce demand for solar PV systems and harm Enphase Energy's business.
• Government incentives such as feed-in tariffs (FiTs), NEM tariffs, rebates, tax credits, and tax incentives are expiring, phasing out, or being changed due to changing market circumstances or energy policy changes.
• If the Investment Tax Credit (ITC) or Alternative Minimum Personal Tax Credit (AMPTC) is reduced or eliminated, sales of Enphase Energy's products in North America could be adversely affected.
• Several European countries have adopted reductions in or ended their NEM or FiT programs, which has significantly impacted the solar industry in Europe and may affect future demand for solar energy solutions.
• Changes to National Energy Market (NEM) policies may reduce demand for electricity from Enphase Energy's solar service offerings.

Item 1C. Cybersecurity.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART I - Item 1C. Cybersecurity section in bullet points:

• ENPH relies heavily on information technology and data to operate its business, with critical systems including computer networks, third-party hosted services, communications systems, software, personal computers, and servers.
• ENPH maintains risk assessment processes to identify cybersecurity threats related to its Information Technology and Confidential Data, and assess potential material impact to its business.
• The company implements and maintains risk management processes to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of its Information Technology and Confidential Data.
• ENPH identifies cybersecurity threats through various methods, including monitoring the threat environment, subscribing to reports and services, analyzing reports of threats and actors, conducting scans of the threat environment, evaluating its and industry's risk profile, and conducting vulnerability assessments.
• The company has a process for escalating certain cybersecurity incidents from its security team up through its security leadership and ultimately to management.
• ENPH has implemented measures to prevent, detect, respond to, mitigate, and recover from identified and significant cybersecurity threats, including technical, physical, and organizational processes.

Item 3. Legal Proceedings.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - Item 3. Legal Proceedings section in bullet points:

• On May 29, 2024, a putative securities class action complaint was filed against ENPH, its CEO, and CFO (collective "Defendants") in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California, captioned Bialic v. Enphase Energy, Inc., Case No. 3:24-cv-03216-BLF.

• On July 15, 2024, a second putative class action complaint was filed naming the same Defendants in the same court, captioned Hayes v. Enphase Energy, Inc., Case No. 3:24-cv-04249.

• The Bialic Action and the Hayes Actions allege that Defendants made false and/or misleading statements in violation of Sections 10(b) and 20(a) of the Exchange Act and Rule 10b-5 promulgated thereunder.

• On or about July 23, 2024, the plaintiff in the Bialic Action voluntarily dismissed the case.

• On or about July 29, 2024, six additional stockholders filed motions to be appointed lead plaintiff and have their selection of counsel appointed as lead counsel.

• The Court held a hearing on the lead plaintiff motions on September 5, 2024, but has not yet issued a decision.

• On December 13, 2024, a third putative class action complaint was filed naming ENPH, its CEO, and its Chief Products Officer (collective "Defendants II") in the same court, captioned Trustees of the Welfare and Pension Funds of Local 464A v. Enphase Energy, Inc., Case No. 3:24-cv-09038.

• The Pension Fund Action alleges that Defendants II made false and/or misleading statements in violation of Sections 10(b) and 20(a) of the Exchange Act and Rule 10

Item 5. Market for the Registrant’s Comm.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - Item 5. Market for the Registrant’s Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities in bullet points:

• Our common stock has traded on The Nasdaq Global Market under the stock symbol “ENPH” since March 30, 2012.
• As of February 3, 2025, there were approximately 16 holders of record of our common stock.
• We have never paid any cash dividends on our common stock and currently anticipate retaining funds to invest in business growth and operation.
• In July 2023, our board authorized the $1.0 billion 2023 Repurchase Program, which has $398.6 million remaining as of December 31, 2024.
• During the three months ended December 31, 2024, we repurchased 2,883,438 shares at a weighted average price of $69.25 per share for an aggregate amount of $199.7 million.

Item 7. Management’s Discussion and Anal.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART II - Item 7. Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations section:

• As of December 31, 2024, ENPH has shipped approximately 80.0 million microinverters.
• Approximately 4.7 million Enphase residential and commercial systems have been deployed in more than 160 countries.
• The company prioritized providing great customer service, scaling business processes, increasing efficiencies, reducing operating costs, and developing hardware and software to enhance its Enphase Energy System offering.
• ENPH expanded its operations with contract manufacturers in the United States with a capacity to produce five million microinverters per quarter.
• The domestic content bonus tax credit is only available to commercial asset owners, which includes commercial businesses adding solar and PPA/lease providers who own residential solar projects.

Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Di.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART II - Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk section in bullet points:

• The company operates in foreign countries where its foreign entities use local currency as their functional currency, exposing them to movements in foreign currency exchange rates.
• Foreign currency exposure primarily arises from payables and receivables related to transactions denominated in euros, Indian Rupee, Brazilian real, Mexican peso, Australian, Canadian, and New Zealand dollars.
• As of December 31, 2024, the company had $1,717.6 million in cash, cash equivalents, restricted cash, and marketable securities.
• The percentage of net revenues denominated in euros was 21% in 2024, 28% in 2023, and 17% in 2022.
• A hypothetical 10% adverse change in foreign exchange rates on December 31, 2024, would not be material to the company's financial condition or results of operations.
• The company has not engaged in any foreign currency hedging transactions and does not enter into derivative financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes.

Item 8. Financial Statements and Supplem.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART II - Item 8. Financial Statements and Supplementary Data section in bullet points:

• As of December 31, 2024, and 2023, Enphase Energy, Inc.'s consolidated balance sheets present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Company.
• The Company's internal control over financial reporting was audited as of December 31, 2024, and an unqualified opinion was expressed on February 7, 2025.
• The warranty obligation provides for the repair or replacement of microinverter and storage products that fail during the product's warranty term, generally of 10 to 25 years.
• The Company's financial statements are the responsibility of management, while the auditor is responsible for expressing an opinion on the financial statements based on the audit.

Item 9A. Controls and Procedures.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - Item 9A. Controls and Procedures section in bullet points:

• As of December 31, 2024, ENPH's principal executive officer and principal financial officer concluded that the company's disclosure controls and procedures were effective to provide reasonable assurance that information required to be disclosed is recorded, processed, summarized, and reported within specified time periods.

• The company's internal control over financial reporting was assessed based on criteria set forth in Internal Control – Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (2013) and was found to be effective as of December 31, 2024.

• There were no changes in internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the most recent year ended December 31, 2024 that materially affected or are reasonably likely to materially affect the company's internal control over financial reporting.

• The company's disclosure controls and procedures and internal control over financial reporting are designed to provide reasonable assurance of achieving their objectives, but no control system can provide absolute assurance against errors, fraud, or undetected control issues.

Item 10. Directors, Executive Officers a.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART III - Item 10. Directors, Executive Officers and Corporate Governance section in bullet points:

• The information about directors is incorporated by reference from the "Election of Directors" section in the company's definitive Proxy Statement for the 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders.
• The information about executive officers is incorporated by reference from the "Management" section in the company's Proxy Statement.
• The company has a Policy Against Trading on the Basis of Inside Information governing the purchase, sale and/or other dispositions of securities by directors, officers, and employees.
• A copy of the company's Code of Conduct is available on its website at http://investor.enphase.com/corporate-governance or upon request to the Secretary.
• The company intends to promptly disclose any substantive amendments to its Code of Conduct or waivers from provisions of the Code of Conduct on its website.

Item 12. Security Ownership of Certain B.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART III - Item 12. Security Ownership of Certain Beneficial Owners and Management and Related Stockholder Matters:

• The company's 5% or greater stockholders' security ownership information is incorporated by reference from the section "Security Ownership of Certain Beneficial Owners and Management" in the Proxy Statement.
• The company's directors and executive officers' security ownership information is also incorporated by reference from the same section in the Proxy Statement.
• Information regarding securities authorized for issuance under the company's equity compensation plans is incorporated by reference from the section "Equity Compensation Plan Information" in the Proxy Statement.
